Said one state senator:  â€œIn government, weâ€™re used to being able to have a public hearing, to talk about these things and get information, and they refused to do it. Nondisclosure agreements are common in the tech industry. Whether government officials beholden to the public interest should be signing NDAs with corporations is now being called into question thanks to Amazon, Foxconn, Google, and other big tech companies.

Trump's tweets and public statements suggest that what California needs to do to prevent wildfires is hoard water and cut down trees to prevent fires spreading.  There's a whole lot more to it than that. https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/peteraldhous/logging-forest-california-wildfires?bftwnews&utm_term=4ldqpgc#4ldqpgcÂ â€¦

Californiaâ€™s escalating problems with destructive wildfires have been driven by a warming, drying climate, and a massive expansion of housing in what experts call the wildlandâ€“urban interface. https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/peteraldhous/california-wildfires-people-climate?bftwnews&utm_term=4ldqpgc#4ldqpgcÂ â€¦

In drawing attention to forest management, Trump has tapped into a contentious scientific debate: Can the American Westâ€™s growing problems with wildfire be solved, in part, by thinning overgrown forests? pic.twitter.com/ID4YmZNC8x

Across the West as a whole, however, thereâ€™s little hard evidence that thinning forests will do much to reduce damaging wildfires.  That hasnâ€™t stopped state, federal, and environmental groups from coming together to thin Californiaâ€™s forests in an attempt to reduce fire risks.

The circumstances of California's worst fires donâ€™t suggest that forest thinning would have helped much.   The Woolsey fire, which just devastated Malibu, and the Thomas fire, which raged around Santa Barbara at the end of 2017, both burned through scrubland, not forests.

Experts say cutting trees and clearing undergrowth around homes, however, makes sense, as does making homes more fire-resistant.  â€œThis is a home ignition problem much more than a wildland management problem." https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/peteraldhous/logging-forest-california-wildfires?bftwnews&utm_term=4ldqpgc#4ldqpgcÂ â€¦

When Father Kuriakose Kattuthara was found dead, it was on a school day. By the time police arrived, the body was already moved to the morgue.   Many fear that one of the biggest scandals to hit the Catholic Church in India will be buried with the priest.  https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/nishitajha/india-catholic-church-bishop-mulakkal-father-kuriakoseÂ â€¦

Thatâ€™s because Kuriakose was a key witness in a case in which a powerful bishop has been accused of raping a nun. The case is tearing Indiaâ€™s Catholic Church apart. https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/nishitajha/india-catholic-church-bishop-mulakkal-father-kuriakoseÂ â€¦

The story connects to a global context: the Catholic Church has been beset by sex abuse crimes in recent years. The last decade has seen the Vatican move from insisting other religions are just â€œas rife with abuseâ€ to the pope condemning these crimes and â€œbegging forgiveness.â€
African Union hit by sexual harassment claims https://bbc.in/2R8s3NfÂ

In India, there are 20 million Catholics, out of 28 million Christians â€” the third-largest religious group after Hindus and Muslims.   Victims of sexual abuse have found it almost impossible to get their allegations taken seriously, let alone bring them before a court.

This year, four priests from a southern state in India have been accused of sex crimes. But the case of Bishop Franco Mulakkal is the biggest of all â€” heâ€™s the man accused of raping the nun, and he became the first Indian bishop to ever be arrested. pic.twitter.com/wYhSavxH7E

Kuriakose was the lone priest to break ranks with the church and testify against the bishop. Taking a brave stance in supporting the nun, he could have bolstered her case by his further testimony in court.

His death could produce a chilling effect on those who want to speak out against abuse by the clergy. Other nuns who supported their sister after she accused the bishop of rape have said they are afraid for their lives since Kuriakoseâ€™s death. pic.twitter.com/Zhuy87CRUs

Now, while police say the priest died a natural death, his family says he may have died under suspicious circumstances.   It seems many in the church would rather forget he ever existed. THREAD  It's been two months since a massive earthquake and powerful tsunami struck the Indonesian island of Sulawesi.  Children were heartrendingly separated from their parents but recent weeks have seen some extraordinary reunions.  Here are two incredible accounts. â¤ï¸ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ‘¦ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ‘¦â€ğŸ‘¦ pic.twitter.com/zlvKbHLwQp

Little Jumadil was building sandcastles on the beach when the earthquake hit.  "Children's corpses were everywhere," says his mother Susi Rahmatia, who collapsed and cried.  "I thought for sure my son had been killed by the waves."   https://bbc.in/2DMQnA8Â  pic.twitter.com/e3ExheUglp

A desperate search for Jumadil began.  His uncle posted this on Facebook - setting the stage for a reunion.  Miraculously, it reached a local woman who came across the boy at a police station and recognised him.  The rest is history. pic.twitter.com/HpeZEdBB0h

"It's an absolute miracle he came back," Jumadil's grandfather says.  We are happy to report that he hugged his mother so tight, he never wanted to let go.  https://bbc.in/2DMQnA8Â  pic.twitter.com/afv9C1F6Kd
Here's a video that captures Jumadil's happy, emotional reunion with his family.  [Tap to expand]   https://bbc.in/2DMQnA8Â  pic.twitter.com/uPGIxFtR2K
This is the story of another lost child, seven-year-old Fikri.  [Tap to expand]   https://bbc.in/2DMQnA8Â  pic.twitter.com/T3Hh3LiXca

The ordeal started with his grand aunt Martha Salilama, who evacuated their house. When walls shook, she dragged little Fikri out with her.  "They were terrified of getting trapped inside."  https://bbc.in/2DMQnA8Â
It was a good call.  After the earth stopped shaking, Marta left Fikri with neighbours on Palu bay.  But when she came back, the boy was gone.  https://bbc.in/2DMQnA8Â
Fikri's parents live far away from Palu and didn't know.  But the news soon reached them and they were devastated. https://bbc.in/2DMQnA8Â

Fikri's grandmother feared the worst.  "We were almost certain we had lost him," Selfi Salilama said.  "At the hospital we opened body bag after body bag that had a child in it.  Each time a wave of fear washed over us, each time we hoped it wasn't Fikri."  https://bbc.in/2DMQnA8Â  pic.twitter.com/CtrMG29K3l

The family banded together to search for Fikri.  A miracle arrived in the form of a social worker, who knocked at their door.  "They had a photo and it was him!"  The boy was alive and well in North Morowali, 500km away.  https://bbc.in/2DMQnA8Â  pic.twitter.com/27IEXPDlKv
The familyâ€™s happy ending, which was also captured on film.  [Tap to expand]   https://bbc.in/2DMQnA8Â  pic.twitter.com/jOoW9soAfo

The families of Jumadil and Fikri were the lucky ones.  Hundreds of others lost their loved ones in the 2018 #Palu disaster.  The full report from @BBCIndonesia Editor @rebeccahenschke here:  https://bbc.in/2DMQnA8Â  pic.twitter.com/fiHvfbHsju

After realizing what had happened in February 2017, Abigail went to the hospital that night, where nurses took swabs for a rape kit.   Donald Grant Ward, 19, confirmed Abigailâ€™s story to police, and was charged with two counts of rape.

During Wardâ€™s three-day trial, defense attorney Kirk Freeman argued that while his clientâ€™s conduct was â€œungentlemanlyâ€ it wasnâ€™t illegal under Indiana law.   The jury agreed. pic.twitter.com/KhwGIzJXxV

Abigail knew she was having sex. She just didnâ€™t know it was with Ward. pic.twitter.com/ySwVoL5P6b

Abigailâ€™s case has exposed a loophole in the laws of not just Indiana, but more than three-quarters of US states and territories: The word consent, when it does appear in a statute, is not expressly defined in laws. pic.twitter.com/aLsgLFf3La

Versions of rape by fraud laws exist in only a handful of US jurisdictions, including California, Missouri, and Puerto Rico.  After Abigailâ€™s case, thereâ€™s been a push from US lawmakers, as well as sexual assault activists, to criminalize rape by fraud and better define consent. pic.twitter.com/KhgwJMefgq

Wardâ€™s attorney says his client could have been prosecuted for sexual battery, though that would have only covered the initial moment that Ward groped Abigail when she was asleep, not the sex when she woke up. It also carried a maximum prison sentence of 2.5 years.

Most famously, a campaign for Christine Blasey Ford raised $647,610 to help cover her familyâ€™s security, transportation, and temporary relocation costs â€” far more than the $150,000 goal, with leftover funds being donated to organizations helping survivors. https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/remysmidt/christine-blasey-ford-donating-extra-money?bftwnews&utm_term=4ldqpgc#4ldqpgcÂ â€¦

Last year, a shocking video obtained by CNN went viral. In it, a group of sub-Saharan Africans were being auctioned as slaves somewhere in Libya. Offscreen, a slave trader emphasized the strength of the black men for sale. The men were sold for $400 each. https://edition.cnn.com/2017/11/14/africa/libya-migrant-auctions/index.htmlÂ â€¦

In 2018, slavery is very much alive, with a cruel twist â€” people from sub-Saharan Africa are often selling themselves into slavery. Hereâ€™s the story of how one man ended up trapped. A thread:   https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/monicamark/slavery-nigeria-libya?bftwnews&utm_term=4ldqpgc#4ldqpgcÂ â€¦

.@nickswicks has been investigating a universe where tens of thousands are detained indefinitely, spend years working without pay, and are at constant risk of being kidnapped, sold, and auctioned from one militia to another. https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/monicamark/slavery-nigeria-libya?bftwnews&utm_term=4ldqpgc#4ldqpgcÂ â€¦

Some experts have argued that in a country like Libya, where chaos reigns, such treatment doesnâ€™t amount to slavery. Their argument overlooks the reality of who ends up being treated this way: pic.twitter.com/UP6ZaED897

The viral video was just the tip of the iceberg of a forced labor market worth $150 billion worldwide. Soon after, videos emerged of Libyan coast guards whipping terrified black women and children at sea. So we followed this story.

Our reporter talked to Jude Ikuenobe, who left his home in Nigeria hoping to make that journey to Europe. Instead, he spent more than two years trying to survive in the underbelly of modern-day slavery. His story is harrowing. pic.twitter.com/gAFgx75mCb

Ikuenobe wasnâ€™t willing to risk everything to get to Europe â€” he just thought slavery was a thing confined to the history books. So when he gave up his savings of 800,000 naira ($2,200), the last thing on his mind was that he would be tortured, then sold.   https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/monicamark/slavery-nigeria-libya?bftwnews&utm_term=4ldqpgc#4ldqpgcÂ â€¦ pic.twitter.com/O806jeFYrz

What do we mean when we say victims â€œsell themselves into slavery?â€ Letâ€™s unpack that. Thousands of desperate people arrive in Libya in hopes of making it across the Mediterranean, in search of a better life in Europe. Some give up the last of their savings for this. pic.twitter.com/FjnYvMYNoX

But itâ€™s much harder to make it to Europe now. As debates rage about the morality of the EUâ€™s â€œstop the boatsâ€ policy, its darkest consequences were often erased from the narrative: the tens of thousands of black Africans entrapped in a growing slave market.
We are proud to follow stories like these. If you want to support more reporting like this, become a BuzzFeed News member today https://support.buzzfeednews.com/Â

Ikuenobeâ€™s journey into slavery was shaped not just by conflict or poverty in Africa, but also directly by Europeâ€™s policies on migration. Yet, at a time when this practice of modern day slavery is at a crisis level, few know anything about it. https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/monicamark/slavery-nigeria-libya?bftwnews&utm_term=4ldqpgc#4ldqpgcÂ â€¦

Fewer migrants are making it to Europe. More are dying, disappearing, or being abused â€” except since itâ€™s no longer happening on the shores of Europe, it rarely appears on the news.   Meanwhile, in the US, President Donald Trump called reports of slaves in Libya â€œfake news.â€

Everyone had to be recruited into the Program, either by another student already in it or by Jensen, who portrayed it as an elite club, according to the lawsuit filed by victims. Lawyers for the victims believe Jensen abused as many as 200 boys in the 1990s.

Jensenâ€™s abuse happened in plain sight. Parents knew their kids went to his house multiple times a week. Various coaches sent boys to him to get full-body massages after football and wrestling practice, even when some boys objected.

Jensen was arrested and charged with 10 counts of child porn, but the statute of limitations will keep him from ever being prosecuted for abusing students.   In Miles City, to say the school district screwed up is to say friends and neighbors failed to stop a child molester.

Many victims are wracked with guilt for having recruited close friends and relatives into the Program only to find out they were later abused. Most have never even told their parents, spouses, or children what happened to them in high school.

Though a document shows the school knew 20 years ago that something was amiss, Jensen was never reported to authorities. Heâ€™s lived alongside many of his victims in Miles City, Montanaâ€” where the county attorney says Jensen often searched for porn involving young boys.

When news of the lawsuit broke, the district said it was â€œshocked.â€ But a 1997 letter to Jensen from school officials shows he was ordered to stop giving â€œbody rub downsâ€ to boys unsupervised, stop inviting boys to spend nights at his home, and end his â€œMentorship Program.â€

Decades later, many of Jensenâ€™s victims are still coming to terms with what they endured, and want justice from the authority figures who failed to protect them.  https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/tylerkingkade/miles-city-james-jensen-fred-anderson-larry-nassar?bftwnews&utm_term=4ldqpgc#4ldqpgcÂ â€¦ pic.twitter.com/DVHRNn34ZS

Thread:  https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/lesterfeder/yanis-varoufakis-unite-europe-left-right-wing-steve-bannon?bftwnews&utm_term=4ldqpgc#4ldqpgcÂ â€¦

Remember Yanis Varoufakis, the motorcycle-driving former Greek finance minister? He rose to fame during Europeâ€™s financial crisis for opposing budget cuts to pay off bad loans.   Now, heâ€™s styling himself as the Bernie Sanders of Europe, trying to give the left a new identity. pic.twitter.com/MGA1bRMqQR

The populists are gaining ground, fast. Look at the numbers on the board: â€¢ Far-right parties lead the government in Italy.  â€¢ They form the largest opposition faction in Germanyâ€™s parliament. â€¢ Hungary is inching closer to dictatorship by the day.  https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/lesterfeder/yanis-varoufakis-unite-europe-left-right-wing-steve-bannon?bftwnews&utm_term=4ldqpgc#4ldqpgcÂ â€¦

In the midsts of this, Varoufakis is trying to solve a central problem: As the right has united, the left dissolved. Many of the continentâ€™s major center-left parties, perhaps because they offer no alternative to the reigning political order, sit on the edge of extinction.

Why is the left so divided? For one thing, the very questions that are forging a natural alliance among the far right â€” immigration, identity, and national sovereignty â€” split the left, in many cases driving a wedge right down the middle of existing parties.

Europeâ€™s volatility and the growing threat of the far right does create an opening for new players to galvanize the left. But Varoufakis is not the only one trying to play the role of savior.  https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/lesterfeder/yanis-varoufakis-unite-europe-left-right-wing-steve-bannon?bftwnews&utm_term=4ldqpgc#4ldqpgcÂ â€¦

As the far right continues to gain ground, the left finally looks like itâ€™s trying to fight back. But will Varoufakisâ€™ movement be enough? Read @jlfederâ€™s profile of a man trying to save Europeâ€™s left. https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/lesterfeder/yanis-varoufakis-unite-europe-left-right-wing-steve-bannon?bftwnews&utm_term=4ldqpgc#4ldqpgcÂ â€¦

His mission is also to energize the left around a common agenda. While the US has exported Breitbart, which boosted Brexit, the kind of progressive surge that launched politicians like Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez has yet to take hold across Europe.

NEW: Russian agents sought secret US Treasury records on Clinton allies weeks before the infamous Trump Tower meeting in 2016. https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/anthonycormier/russian-agents-sought-us-treasury-records-on-clinton-backers?bftwnews&utm_term=4ldqpgc#4ldqpgcÂ â€¦
Russian agents used backchannel communications to press US officials for private financial documents on at least two dozen dissidents, academics, private investigators, and American citizens.

During the presidential campaign, as the Kremlin meddled in the election, Treasury officials were using their government email accounts to exchange messages with a network of private Hotmail and Gmail accounts set up by Russians.

Russian agents sought info on the Ziff brothers, billionaire investors who had run afoul of the Kremlin.  Weeks later, at the now notorious Trump Tower meeting, a Russian lawyer offered Trump aides â€œdirtâ€ on Hillary Clinton, including her supposed connection to the Ziff brothers.

Internal whistleblowers warned Treasury staffers that Russia could be trawling for sensitive financial records â€” including Social Security and bank account numbers â€” to spy on, endanger, or recruit targets in the West. But staffers continued using the Gmail backchannel into 2017.

Insiders warned the backchannel exposed the Treasury to potential hackers because the Russian messages contained attachments â€” a common way for intruders to worm their way inside an organizationâ€™s servers.
German airports on alert amid spying reports at Stuttgart https://bbc.in/2CqtguoÂ

The crisis in France is a byproduct of thousand-year old rivalries in an ancient and fragmented land, writes @KarlreMarks https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/karlsharro/an-ancient-land-beset-by-ancient-rivalries?bftwnews&utm_term=4ldqpgc#4ldqpgcÂ â€¦

The extraordinary departure from protocol is latest evidence of widespread dysfunction at FinCEN, the Treasury Departmentâ€™s elite financial watchdog, which a two-year BuzzFeed News investigation has laid bare.

It was not the only time that concerns about serious counterintelligence threats were raised at FinCEN during the past two years. At least 10 employees have filed formal whistleblower complaints about the department. Some of FinCENâ€™s top officials quit in anger.

The Treasury Department refused to explain why its officials were communicating with unofficial Gmail accounts at the same time as Russia was sending the suspicious requests, or to tell BuzzFeed News whether it eventually turned over any documents in response.

NEW: Prominent evangelical leader and Trump supporter Jerry Falwell Jr. has, for the first time, acknowledged he and his wife put up a $1.8 million loan for a Miami Beach hostel managed by a young pool attendant he got to know at a lavish Miami hotel. https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/aramroston/jerry-falwell-affidavit?bftwnews&utm_term=4ldqpgc#4ldqpgcÂ â€¦

Others involved in the deal sued, saying they were pushed out. In an affidavit, Falwell said he gave the attendant the loan so he would serve as "local manager."    Falwell didnâ€™t say why Giancarlo Granda, age 21 when they met, was selected for the job. pic.twitter.com/i8eJ1iXMwl

Falwell played a key role in the 2016 presidential election, when he abruptly endorsed Trump and helped to deliver the overwhelming support of white Christian evangelicals.   We previously reported that Michael Cohen helped broker the crucial endorsement. https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/aramroston/jerry-falwell-jr-michael-cohen-pool-attendant-lawsuit?bftwnews&utm_term=4ldqpgc#4ldqpgcÂ â€¦

In an unrelated case, Cohen earlier this month got 3 years in prison after pleading guilty to tax fraud, lying to Congress, and campaign finance crimes related to payments made on behalf of Trump. https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/amberjamieson/michael-cohen-sentenced-mueller-trump-tower-russia-stormy?bftwnews&utm_term=4ldqpgc#4ldqpgcÂ â€¦

In 2012, the year Granda and Falwell developed what the lawsuit calls a â€œfriendly relationship,â€ Granda was introduced to Trump at Liberty University, where he gave a convocation speech. Cohen also attended. It's unclear why Granda, who was not a Liberty student, was there.

Social media platforms take down graphic violent videos but investigators worry they are erasing evidence of war crimes   https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/meghara/facebook-youtube-icc-war-crimes?bftwnews&utm_term=4ldqpgc#4ldqpgcÂ â€¦

A Facebook friend request exposed decades of sex abuse in a high school. A lawsuit says up to 200 kids may have been victims. https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/tylerkingkade/miles-city-james-jensen-fred-anderson-larry-nassar?bftwnews&utm_term=4ldqpgc#4ldqpgcÂ â€¦

The Libya conflict, which started in 2011, was the first major war that took place entirely during the social media era. Militants and civilians documented the conflict in real time.  This has fundamentally shifted how war crimes are prosecuted. A thread:  https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/meghara/facebook-youtube-icc-war-crimes?bftwnews&utm_term=4ldqpgc#4ldqpgcÂ â€¦

Militants and ordinary Libyans began posting thousands of videos of brutality to social media. But for academics, activists and war crimes investigators who were looking, this was more than a stream of violence â€” it was a windfall of potential evidence. pic.twitter.com/fLfWsogGK5

This is a huge shift. Investigators documenting abuses used to depend heavily on diaries, records, and interviews with witnesses that sometimes took place years after the fact. Now, the evidence is available immediately â€” sometimes uploaded by militants incriminating themselves.

Investigators at international bodies like the United Nations and the International Criminal Court are harvesting, cataloging, and analyzing millions of photos, posts, and videos from social media in an effort to hold human rights abusers accountable in court. pic.twitter.com/ySa6HrCABJ

However, their efforts are coming up against another shift: social media companies are facing unprecedented criticism for failing to police their platforms, allowing neo-Nazis and other extremist groups to spread their messages online.  https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/meghara/facebook-youtube-icc-war-crimes?bftwnews&utm_term=4ldqpgc#4ldqpgcÂ â€¦

Those platforms have continued to struggle with addressing the criticism. Meanwhile, the videos of executions and other extremely graphic violence have become low-hanging fruit for the platforms to take down and show that theyâ€™re trying to do something.

The removal of this kind of content is posing a major problem for researchers who are using it for documentation. If the history of conflicts is being written in social media, what happens when it disappears? https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/meghara/facebook-youtube-icc-war-crimes?bftwnews&utm_term=4ldqpgc#4ldqpgcÂ â€¦
